travels.title: Guatemala '09
travels.headertext: In February 2009, Allan and Crystal joined us for a nine day visit to Guatemala. One of our chief reasons for going to Guatemala was to visit Brian Stipek. Brian runs Embrace Guatemala, a charity designed to help the indigenous Ixil inhabitants of the area around a small town called Nebaj. We started our visit in Antigua, the old colonial capital of Guatemala. After a full day there, we traveled with Brian to the Nebaj region via 'chicken bus' and microbus. Brian introduced us to some of the families of the area and we enjoyed a number of meals in their homes. After Nebaj, we headed to Lake Atitlan where we explored several of the towns surrounding the lake. Finally, it was back to Antigua for another short visit before heading home.

entry.text: Antigua is the original colonial capital of Guatemala. It was mostly leveled in 1773 by an earthquake. Many old ruins are still standing. Nowadays, Antigua is where Guatemalans of means and foreigners mainly hang out. In addition to the beautiful old ruins, nice hotels and restaurants abound.
In addition to the earthquakes, Antigua is surrounded by volcanoes. The one known as Volcan Fuego is almost continually active. It would occasionally send up ash clouds when we were there.

From Antigua we traveled by 'chicken bus' and microbus to Nebaj. Nebaj, in the northwest part of Guatemala is home to the Ixil people. Brian is based there. We did a number of hikes around Nebaj. The terrain is rugged and beautiful.

Brian arranged for us to share meals with some of the local Ixil families in their homes. The local cuisine is mainly centered on corn, beans and eggs. The food was really good, and the tortillas are always fresh off the stove. One of the most enjoyable aspects of the Ixil region is that most of the women still wear traditional dress. The pattern shown in the picture is typical of Nebaj.

After Nebaj, we went to Lago Atitlan, a large lake in central Guatemala surrounded by volcanoes. We stayed in Panajachel, but took a boat across the lake to visit Santiago and San Pedro. We also did a short walk along the lake to the neighboring town of Santa Catarina.

From Lago Atitlan, we returned for one more full day in Antigua before heading home. The weather was perfect - sunny, warm and clear. All of our travels in Guatemala kept us in the 'highlands' -- high enough to keep above the tropical heat.
